Far far transccnds the proudest works OF art!

Our fond companion; taught to court the gaze

bright silk, by vrtuous hucs diversified,

form

Jhy modest curls, in Wild disorder

bound

From the New-York Mirror.
To A WAIST -RIBAND FOR MARIA.

twas Sunday evening: The last rays oi
the setting sun had tinged the horizon with
gold-the blue vault of heaven was cloudless,
calm and serene. Mingled sounds of pear
ly rivulct. and the bird of song, came steal
ing upon the soul, sweet as the visions oi
youth--soft murmurs broke in upon the still
" silence, like music ON the houi of repose
The lake unrufTled by single areeze,
seemed to smile in its quiet rest, as if storm
aud tempest were thing unknown-its
! boundless depths were glowing brightly as
the polished mirror. with unnumbered trees
and blossoms impressed upon its BOSOM
The gentle zephyr SO lightly breathed upon
the dewy bowers that even the aspen Leaf
would have forgotten its trembling. The
glad earth, which had seen but a few short
months before clad in a wintry g&rment 81
fcecy snow, was now clad in cheerfulness
and smiles, declaring that blight and frost
had passed away.


Mingled recoilections came crowding
thick and fast upon the soul, when on turn


ing an angle in the road, the village Of b,
now my home, burst upon my view in all its
peerless beauty; the much loved trends
left but few months ago, bloon 'rg with
health and happiness might now be slum-
berny in their narrow house of solitude and
silence, aud the bright blossoms Of May
might now be blooming over their resting
placr-s Twas the hour oi
PRAYER. With conntenances beaming with
health and hope, with hearts beating high
with gratitude to the Author Of all good, the
children Of the Most High came up TO the
feast of the ta5ernacles. There, before the
altar-there in the temple OF the Eternal,
was raised the anthem and the song ct Him
who made the world. Not to appease his
vengeance did his children bow before him,
but to thank him for that kindness and the
care which knows no bound. At this hour so
beautiful aud brght-the type OF the glori-
Gus world where tears and sighs are never
known-when the soul is filed with joy and
rladness-'ts there in that soft hour OF
peace, when communing with Him who IS
invisible, that VIC have foretastc ct those
nnspeakablc joys that flow at Gods right
hand-'tis there we look toward to that
bright period. when purged from every I'M
purity and earthly fraiIty, we shall wing our
way to a home of glory, where our praises
will be without trembling and our thanks
givings unmingled with tears. l.s.
IIOME--A FRAGMENT.

The climate Of Cuba is remarkably fine
and salubrious for a considerable part of the
wear; say from the month of October to the
first of June. During this period the ther-
mometer ranges from 70 to 80 degrees Far.
and for the remaining part of the year is a
little above 80, though rarely so high as 90,
1t will be seen by this that it is not subject
to those severe and sudden changes which
occur in our own country, and which are so
extremely fatal in the production of pulmo..
nary complaints. The subject of the climate
of the city of Havanns. is but little under
stood IN the United States. The locality of
the city is certainly as favorable tor health
as most cities of equal magnitude in the u
nited States. For the two years previous to
the 3Ist December, 1926, there was no yell
low fever there, although the rainy season
must be productive of much filth in the
streets as they are during the winter season
very dusty, and little or no pains are taken
to remove this dust. Several American
physicians of good reputation are established
at Havana. DR.. -, the eldest of these,
informed me that during his practice he had
lost Of the fever, about one tenth of his pa
tients; that he imputed good deal of the
unhealthiness to the regularity of the trade
winds from the north east. Since the time
the fever had ceased, the winds had been
variable; that he could judge from this
and from the appearance of the water in
the bay, what the state of health would be
by anticipation. On such occasions the wa
ter had muddy appearance, and, he add.
ed, "whitsh." Dr.. c.. another physician
Of equally good standing, mentioned that dur
ing the last fever, he had, out of 1913 pa
tients, lost Is. This, it will be seen, is more
than the proportion mentioned by the first
statement: but the first was general. without
reference to any particular year. Both add
ed that when death cnsued, in most instan-
ces they had not been called IN season; nor
until the very last stages of the disorder. IN
these cases too, the patients were generally
sailors of foreign nations. However favor"
able this statement may be, II must not DC
forgotten that eMigrants from all parts OF
Europe. not excepting Spain, are subject to
i. the first wear. One young American told
me that during a residence of seven years
at Havana and Matanzas, he had it three
times. Few, after all, of mankind will be
willing TO take the chance of life and death,
even of one in ten. Although it must be
admitted that many die from indulging in
habits contracted previously to their resi-
deuce in Cuba; and from the sudden change
of diet and custom. 1t might be well tor
people on that account, to locate themselves
in such public houses as would be found to
correspond most with their previous habits
and manners, particularly during their early
residence in Cuba.


The Island, from its peculiar sslubrity
during the season from November to May,
of course offers great inducements to persons
afflicted with pulmonary complaints. Hence
it is visited great deal on this account
The country is generally preferred to The
cities, and numbers of invalids are found on
the plantations in various parts Of the !slard

LETTER x.

Amongst too many ether instances OF the
great corruption and degeneracy OF the age
wherein we live, the great and general want
of sincerity in conversation is none of the
last. The world is grown so full OF dissimu-
lation and compliment, that mems words are
hardly any signihcaton of their thoughts
The old plainness and sincerity, that gener-
Gus integrity of nature, and honesty OF dis
position, which always argues true great
ness of mind, and is usually accompanied
with undaunted courage and resolution, is in
great measure lost amongst US.


The dialect of conversation is, now a-days,
so sweled with vanity and compliment, and
so surfeited (if you allow me the expression)
with kindness and respect, that it man
who lived century ago should return into
the world again, he would really want die
tionary to help I'm to understand his own
language, and to know the true intrinsic val
ue of the phrase in fashion and would hard
ly at FIRST believe at what low rate the
highest strains and expressions of kindness
do commonly pass in current payment; and
when he should come to understand it, it
would be a great while before he coald
bring himself, with good countenance and
good conscience, to converse with men up
on equal terms, and in their own way. And.
in truth, it is hard to say, whetherit it should
more provoke our contempt or our pity, TO
hear what selemn expressions of respect ana
Kindness will pass between men, almost up
on no occasion; how great honor and esteem
they will declare for one, whom, perhaps,
they never saw before and how entirely
they are, all on a sudden, devoted to his ser
vice and interest, for no reason I! how inf
nitely and eternally obliged to him, for no
benefit! and how extremely they will be
concerned for him, yea, and afflicted too tor
no cause!
SINCERITY IN CONVERSATION.

! Woman is a very nice and very compli-
Gated machine. Her springs are infinitely
delicate: and differ from those ot man pref
ty nearly as the work of a repeating watch
does from that Of town-clock. Look at
her body; how deicatcly formed Exam
inc her senses; how exquisite and nice! Ob-
serve her under standing; how subtle and a
cute! But look inte her heart; composed OF
parts SO minute in themselves, and SO won
derfully combined, that they must be seen
by a microscopic eye to be clearly compre-
hended.


The perception of a woman is as quick as
lightning. Her penetration is intuition; ]
had almost said instinct. BY glance OF
her eve she shall draw deep and ust con-
clusion. Ask her how she formed 1t; she can
not answer the question.


As the perception of women is surprising
ly quick; so their souls and d,imaginations are
uocommonly susceptible Few of them have
culture enough to write; but when they do,
how lively are their pictures! how animat-
ed their descriptions But it few women
write. they all talk; and every man may
Judge of them in this point, from every circ,e
he goes into. Spirit in conversation depends
entirely upon fancy; and women an over the
world talk better than men. Rave they Il
characterize portray, or f1gure 20 oescrlpe!
thev give but three traits of either one or the
other, and the character is known or the
6gure placed before our eyes. Why From
the susceptibility of their imaginatt'ons their
fancies receive lively impressions from those
principal traits, and they paint those I'M
pressions with the same vivacity with which
they receive them. o,vors,
Let a woman of fancy warm in tonversa-
tion, she shall produce hundred charming
images, among which there shall NOT DC Que
indelicare or coarse. Warm man on .ne


same subject; he shall possibly fna s.rohgnr .,;,


allusions, but they shall neither DC 30 oFii-
liant nor SO chaste,

WOMAN.

VOL. ~.

There are not two other words in the lam
guage that call back a more fruitful train ol
past remembranccs of friendship. than these
Look through YOUR library, and when you
cast your eve upon volume that contains
the name of an old compainion, 1t will say
remember me. Have you AN ancient album
the repository Of the mementos Of early
affection! Turn over is leaves, stained by
the finger uf tine--sit down aud ponder up
on the names enrolled upon them; each says
remember me. Gointo the crowded church
ward, among the marble tonbs s-read tine
simple and brief inscriptions tina. perpetuate
the memory Of departed ones; they too have
voice that speaks to the hearts OF the liv-
ing. and it says--remem5er M. Walk in
the hour of evening twilight and the scenes
of YOUR early rambles; the we'll known
maths. the winding streams, the overspread'
ing trees, the green and gently sloping bar rs
will recall the dreams of juvenile pleasure,
and the recollections Of youthful companions;
thev too bear the treasured Injunction
member mr..


And this is all that is left at last of the
wide circle of our early friends. Scattered
by fortune, or called away by death, or
thrown without our band by the changes OF
circumstance or Of character-in time, we
find ourselves alone with the recollection OF
what they were. Snme were our beneiactors
and won us l,y their favors; others were kind,
amiabe and affectionate, and for this we cs-
tecmed them; others again were models otvIr-
tue, and shared our praise and admiration. 1t
wasthus little while, and then the chances OF
the world broke in upon the delightful inter-
course; it ceased. Yet still, we do all we
can to discharge the one sacred, honest and
honorable deht-7ce remember them.


The tribute, too, Of remembrance Which
we delight to pay to others, we desire TOR
ourselves. The wish for applause; the
thirst for fame; the desire that our names
should shine down to future posterity in
the glory Of recorded deeds, is feverish,
unhappy passion, compared with the unam-
bilious desire to retain, even beyond the
span oflfc, the affections ofthe warm heart
ed few who shared our JOYS and sorrows IN
the world. I once read the bret inscription


-'remember me, on tomb stone IN a coun-
try church ward, with tear, that the grave
oe Bonaparte would not have called forth.


But whom do we always remember with
affrction9 the virtuous, the kind, the warm
hearted: those who have endearc1 them
selves to us BY the amiableness Of their char
actors. 1t is the mind. the disposition, the
habits, the feelings of our friends whish at
toch us to them most strongly; which form
the oulv lasting bond of affection; Which
lone can secure our affectionate remembran-
ces


Then if we would be remembered with
the kindliest feelings; if We would be en-
balmed in the memory If those we love, IT


we desire that when fortune or fate shall
seperate US from our friends, they may long
t,;nt of ne. we must Dossess ourselves the
same cbaracteY VIC love in others. Never
was there more noble line written in the
history of man, than this-'the first emotion
of pain he ever causeI-was caused by his
departure
REMEMBER ME.

know it is said, in justification of this
hollow kind of conversation, that there is
no harm, no real deceit, in compliment-but
that the matter is well enough, so long as we
understand one anothcr:-yer6a Uaienf ut
numni-7vords are like money:-and when
the current value of them is generally un-
derstood, no man is cheated by them. This
is something, if such words are any thing;
but, being brought into the account, they
are mere ciphers.-However, it is just mat
ter of compliment, that sincerity and hlain-
ness are out of fashion, and that our Lam
guage is running into lie; that men have
almost perverted the use of speech, and
made words to signify nothing; that the
greater part of the conversation of mankind
is little else but driving trade of Gissimu-
latjon. insomuch, that it would make a man
sick and weary of the world to see the little
sincerity that is in use and practice among
men.


lfthe show of any thing be good for any
thing, am sure sincerity is better; for why
does any man dissemble, or seem to be that
which he is not. but because he thinks it
good to have such quality as he pretends
to- for to counterfeit and dssemble, is to
put on the appearance of some real excel
lency. Now the best way in the world to
seem to be any thing, is really to be what he
would seem to be. Besides that. it is many
times as troublesome to make good the pre-
tence of a good quality, as to have it; and if
man has it not, it is ten to one but he is
discovered to want it; and then all his pains
and labor to seem to have it, are lost. What
soever convenience may be thought to be
in taischood and dissimulation, it is soon over;
but the inconvenience OF it is perpetual be-
cause it brings man under AN everlasting
,a,l1 !. g. L.
lieved when he speaks the truth-nor trust
ed when perhaps he means honesty. When
tnan has once forfeited the reputation of
his Integrity, he is set free; and nothing will
then serve his turn, neither truth nor false
hood.

Effects Of Moonlight uhon the Eyes,
The effect ofthe mo 'nlight on the eyes, in
Egypt, is sngularly injurious: the natives
tell you, as found afterwards they did in
Arabia, to cover your eyes when you sleep
in the open air. The moon in Egypt strikes
and affects the sight, when you sleep expos
ed to it, much more than the sun; a fact Of
which l had very unpleasant proof one
night, and took care to guard against it at-
terwards; indeed, the sight of a person who
should sleep with his face exposed at night
would soon be utterly impaired or destroyed,

Many years ago, the judges on one of the
circuits were detained so late on Saturday
night, at a certain assize town, that being
obliged to op'n the commission at the next
town On the Monday following they were
compelled, much against their will to travel
between the two places on the Sabbath dav;
but to do this with decent and jnaee-like
proprietv, it was SO managed that they
should breakfast at an inconsidcrable town.
or rather village, about half way-stay and
attend divine service there--and then pro-


ceed to their destination.


On their arrival at this midway hamlet,


whose rustic inhahitants were in that torpid
and dreamy state so common in a small coIn-
try place, and who AS much expected his
majesty in person. as two of his malesty's
Judges. at their little church on that day,
the landlord of the village ale-house, called
by courtesy an inn, was made acquainted


with their intentions, and instantly despatch
ed his head waiter, alias pot boy, alias host
Ter to the SEXTON, with the marvellous IT,
linps: the sexton made il known to the over
seers. church wardens. and rector; they to
.heiy resDectivc wives; their wives to all the
housema,ds. nurscmaids, and cooks; till, by
some freemasonrv sign, some tfleEraph'c
movement or some other occult mode OF
communication, the whole parish knew OF
the intended honor, before their legal lord
eh;ps had dispatched the comfortable and
substantial breakfast, which mine host of
the Red Lion, with an inhnitude OF bows,
scrapes, and apologies, had set before them
Great was the rummaging ot trunks, and
tumblinp over of the contents of drawers, on
this eventful morning; all the best blbs and
fuckers were had in requisition; the SILK
pown of the elderly dame, and the delicate


white muslin envelope of the younger lady,
were brought forth; and much was the RI


varv of the female part OF the congregation;


while the gentlemen were not oehino-nanu
in furnishing up their attire, and even the
rustic laborers gave their shoes ana hlgh-
Ions an extra polish, and hid their sunday
clothes under their whitest and best stitch-
ed smock trocks. All, in short, were de-
termined to do their best to show the Judg-
es that they we're properly sensible OF tne
high honor done them; and more especiai-
". all those in authority, From the rector
down to the parsh-clerK, maze up ther
minds to do something that might be pleas
ing to their unexpected visiters.


First. a sort of procession was formed,
consisting of the old beadle, areheaded,
hearing his tarnished laced hat in one hand,
and his staff of Office in the other; then came
the overseers. and then the church wardens,
bearing certain willow wands in their hands,
which had been rudely separated from their
native stems. and hastily stripped OF their
bark for the great occasion, last but not
least. came the well-fed rector, side by side
with the Judges, and honored as he walked
by sundry scraps oftheir learned conversa,,
ton. Thus they reached the ivy-covered
fame; the inhabitants, cap in hand, forming
an avenue from the gate of the churchyard
to the door of the church, and were usher
ed into the only pew conscious of once green
baize, but which had become venerably vel,
low by extreme old age. The church had
not been so still. during divine service, per-
haps for ages; the wayward urchins, who
generally contrived, by their contumacious
Behaviour, their munching of apples. or
cracking Of nuts, to get lasts OF the hea-
AN AWKWARD COMPLIMENT.

hrokena And the remembrance of earthly
scenes, are they indeed to the enfranchised
spirit as the morning dream, or the dew up


on the early Howers Reflections such as


these naturally arise in every breast. Their


influence is felt, though their import cannot


always be expressed. The principle is the


same, however it may differ in its opera
tions.o

:. The annexed paragraph is an eloquent de-
hneation of what all can feel, but Jew can
Soeloquently describe. 1t is from the novel
e0t'tIed-"Narriage"-a work written with

There is, perhaps, no feeling of our ma"
.ure SO vague complicated, SO mysterious, as
mat with which we look upon the cold re-
mans of our fellow mortals. The dignity
with which death invests the meanest OF its
victims, inspires us with an awe no living
creature can create. The monarch on his
.lrone is less awful than the beggar in his
,,'roud. The marble features-the power
'ess hand-the stiffened limb--oh! who can
sso'nntemplate these with feelings that can be
SSehhed! These are the mockery of all our
hh0pes and fears, our fondest love, our tellest
hha'e' Can it he, that we now shrink with
n no'ror from the touch Of that hand which but
33tes.ercay was fondly clasped in our own! Is
o' o"a' tongue, whose accents even now dwell IN
Tn TSl forever chained in the silence of death!
foas fSnese black and heavy eye-lids, are they
wher teVer TO seal up in darkness the eyes
strs; an1se glance no earthly power could re-
elm And the spirit which animated the
o. , s; wnere is it now? 1t is wrapped in bliss
~ a,ssolved in woe! Does it witness our grief,
TO- ~ snare our sorrows? Or is the mysterious
h2ss tnat linked il with mortality forever

All must die; kings, princes must obey
The freezing CALI Statesmen must ono day


stoop


Iopay their court to the despotic tomb;
Lawyers must there refund the fee of life;
Heroes. unarrned, forgetting sieges. battles,
Must, far from glory, and the sound ofpraise,
lake their last stations inspired orators
Must shun the multitude, whose mind they made,
And cleave to silence and oblivion.
The player must desert his mimic scene,
T., 10 die indeed; and poets, fond of hope.
With their fine sense of life, must humble too,
And, at the summons, quit Castalia's springs,
10 plunge amid the gloom Of Erebus.


us to the wretch alone that he denies

dies cane. were dumb .foundered by the
presence of men. who they imagined had
the power TO transport them-nay, hang
them, for aught they knew, for any III De-
haviour, or appearance of contempt, in their
august society.


Service degan. The rustic choir endcav-
ored to "snatch grace beyond the reach of
art" but some of their tongues seemed to
tceave to the roofs of their mouths; the rec
tors sermon was the best he could pick out
from his bundle Of ffty-two, or thereabouts,
which bundle having served for one year,
was then turned round and served mighti-
ly well for the next also; his auditors. sim
! pie souls never suspecting that they were
getting the same dose over again.


At this church, the custom was to dismiss
the congregation with psalm, or portion
os one; and the clerk (who was a celebrat-
ed singer Of profane melodies at the Red
Lion atoresaid) generally reserved his best
piece of psalmody to conclude with; and at
the time in question, being determined, like
all the rest, to immortalize himself as much
as might be. he looked into the index to the
psalms, and finding that the ffty-eighth
psalm began With Speak, 0 We Judges of
the earth" he thought he had hit upon the
very thing that would do; and when the rev.
erend rector had concluded his sermon,
boldly gave out the first four verses of the
aforesaid psalm, expecting, no doubt, APP
plause and reward accordingly. The pitch
pipe granted and groaned, the singers growl-
"a their stcntorian voices into something
like unison, and off they went in grand
st, le, and sang as follows:


"Spcak, ye Judges Of the earth,
If Just your sentence be;


Or must not innocence appeal


To heaven from your decree'


Your wicked hearts and iudments are


Alike by malice swave;


Your gripping hands, by weighty bribes,


To violence betrayed.


To virtue, strangers from the womb,


Their infant steps went wrong


They prattle SANDER, and in lies


Employed their lispng tongue.


No scrpe' of pnrched Africa's breed


Doth ranker poison bear;


The drowsy adder will soon


Unlock his sullen ear"


1t may readily be supposed that the con-
gregation presently began to find out that
the clerks compliment was completely mai
GhrohoS; as to those who were called, par
excellence, the regular singers, they went
on with their work as loud as usual; not be-
ing in the habit oftroubing thel heads about
the import of the words they were singing;
but those Of the congre cation who some
times helped them in their chanting, and
who on this occasion, began as usual, upon
finding the tenor (this is not meant for mu-
sca pun) of the psalm, dropped their voices
one after another, ard left all the glory and
the shame to the singing pew. The clerk
too was frightened out of lis wits, or there
abouts, at what he had done; and doubtless
expected some dreadful visitation from the
strong arm If the law for his temerity;
while same Of the neighbours were not quite
sure whether heavy fine would not be
lain upon the parish for the insult; in short,
these four verses Of the fifty-eight psalm had
thrown complete gloom upon the day
which had seemed to dawn so glori0usly for
this little parish.


When the judges had returned to the
Red Lion, and were taking lunch TO fortify
their legal stomachs till they should reach
to dinner, deputation OF "the pow
ers that be" waited on them, as well to
thank them for tre honor done to their
explanation tor poor Amen; who felt quite
unable that day 10 do justice to his baked
shoulder of mutton and potatoes. However,
to his infinite comfort, he was assured by
the church wardens, On their return, that
the Judges had kindly promised not to hang
him that time

Friendship may have its origin in esteem,
but sensihility must support 1t.

full articles.headline:
From the New-York Mirror.
To A WAIST -RIBAND FOR MARIA.
full articles.article:
Thou beautiful production OF worm!
oft of an inscctl--a poor reptiles work!
Although thy origin be humble, still
rhou slnilest in native beauty, touching pride
THAT noupht is made in vain; that cen the worm,
whose very name we oatbe, in pomp and sklll,
Far far transccnds the proudest works OF art!
That insect, ola race SO vile, detestabic,
which once we spurned, because 50 fSr benea'h
Our lordy nature, strange to tell! becomes
Our fond companion; taught to court the gaze
ofbeauty, learning, friendship, picty'
'rhon bunblcst thing on earth proclalms His


praise
wbo formed the mountain and the grain OF sand.
bright silk, by vrtuous hucs diversified,
Thy lovely tnts melt in each others KISS,
Like those enriching heavens pure RAINBOW.
What art thou now! the loom has changed thy


form


So very delicate thou vast, that cen
The gcn,lest zephyr, passing DER thee, threw
Jhy modest curls, in Wild disorder
But taste has altered thee; beauty desired;
And 'mong the million strange varieties
That generous nature gives art fixed on thee
On thee, to ornament earth's lovely daughters
On thee most fit to grace immortal beauty!
How various are the uses thou dost serve.
sometimes thou Aowest in robes from forms that


seem


Too fair and heavenly for an earthly home.
Again, entwincd around the golden ringets,
beauteous braid, they look to thee tor succour
More frequent STILL and sure more dearly used,
Thou caspest some gentle form in thy embrace; y;
Her heart the emerald, and thysclf the ring.
The power Of Venus DER the virgin heart
Was strengthened by a girdlc-maglc -one!--
Impartns grace and beauty to its wearer
Thou'rt not forgotten on that holy day,
When in the temple met for prayer and PRAISE
Earth's suffering millions bow before Gods


throne;


The reverend priest seems far more holy, When
Thou veilest Ills bohy from our view.
Dost thou not smile upon the lghtniug's fash,
Like that bright gem, the soul, which, strongly


bound


In pure religions casket, laughs to scorn
The threats of Satan and the darts of hell,
Invulnerahlc meath the shield Of hcavcn
Oh! ifthis lrt'c gift possesses power
AS magic; as mat of Venus zone,
'Twould be supcrAnous-hers gave elegance,
And grace, and beauty to the most deforme a
If mine could boast such skill, what wouldes


thou be-


FArer than forms that haunt the poets brain
Richer than lovers fondcst wish can paint

full articles.headline: IIOME--A FRAGMENT.
full articles.article:
twas Sunday evening: The last rays oi
the setting sun had tinged the horizon with
gold-the blue vault of heaven was cloudless,
calm and serene. Mingled sounds of pear
ly rivulct. and the bird of song, came steal
ing upon the soul, sweet as the visions oi
youth--soft murmurs broke in upon the still
" silence, like music ON the houi of repose
The lake unrufTled by single areeze,
seemed to smile in its quiet rest, as if storm
aud tempest were thing unknown-its
! boundless depths were glowing brightly as
the polished mirror. with unnumbered trees
and blossoms impressed upon its BOSOM
The gentle zephyr SO lightly breathed upon
the dewy bowers that even the aspen Leaf
would have forgotten its trembling. The
glad earth, which had seen but a few short
months before clad in a wintry g&rment 81
fcecy snow, was now clad in cheerfulness
and smiles, declaring that blight and frost
had passed away.


Mingled recoilections came crowding
thick and fast upon the soul, when on turn


ing an angle in the road, the village Of b,
now my home, burst upon my view in all its
peerless beauty; the much loved trends
left but few months ago, bloon 'rg with
health and happiness might now be slum-
berny in their narrow house of solitude and
silence, aud the bright blossoms Of May
might now be blooming over their resting
placr-s Twas the hour oi
PRAYER. With conntenances beaming with
health and hope, with hearts beating high
with gratitude to the Author Of all good, the
children Of the Most High came up TO the
feast of the ta5ernacles. There, before the
altar-there in the temple OF the Eternal,
was raised the anthem and the song ct Him
who made the world. Not to appease his
vengeance did his children bow before him,
but to thank him for that kindness and the
care which knows no bound. At this hour so
beautiful aud brght-the type OF the glori-
Gus world where tears and sighs are never
known-when the soul is filed with joy and
rladness-'ts there in that soft hour OF
peace, when communing with Him who IS
invisible, that VIC have foretastc ct those
nnspeakablc joys that flow at Gods right
hand-'tis there we look toward to that
bright period. when purged from every I'M
purity and earthly fraiIty, we shall wing our
way to a home of glory, where our praises
will be without trembling and our thanks
givings unmingled with tears. l.s.

full articles.headline: CUH.A TN 1s27.
full articles.article:
The climate Of Cuba is remarkably fine
and salubrious for a considerable part of the
wear; say from the month of October to the
first of June. During this period the ther-
mometer ranges from 70 to 80 degrees Far.
and for the remaining part of the year is a
little above 80, though rarely so high as 90,
1t will be seen by this that it is not subject
to those severe and sudden changes which
occur in our own country, and which are so
extremely fatal in the production of pulmo..
nary complaints. The subject of the climate
of the city of Havanns. is but little under
stood IN the United States. The locality of
the city is certainly as favorable tor health
as most cities of equal magnitude in the u
nited States. For the two years previous to
the 3Ist December, 1926, there was no yell
low fever there, although the rainy season
must be productive of much filth in the
streets as they are during the winter season
very dusty, and little or no pains are taken
to remove this dust. Several American
physicians of good reputation are established
at Havana. DR.. -, the eldest of these,
informed me that during his practice he had
lost Of the fever, about one tenth of his pa
tients; that he imputed good deal of the
unhealthiness to the regularity of the trade
winds from the north east. Since the time
the fever had ceased, the winds had been
variable; that he could judge from this
and from the appearance of the water in
the bay, what the state of health would be
by anticipation. On such occasions the wa
ter had muddy appearance, and, he add.
ed, "whitsh." Dr.. c.. another physician
Of equally good standing, mentioned that dur
ing the last fever, he had, out of 1913 pa
tients, lost Is. This, it will be seen, is more
than the proportion mentioned by the first
statement: but the first was general. without
reference to any particular year. Both add
ed that when death cnsued, in most instan-
ces they had not been called IN season; nor
until the very last stages of the disorder. IN
these cases too, the patients were generally
sailors of foreign nations. However favor"
able this statement may be, II must not DC
forgotten that eMigrants from all parts OF
Europe. not excepting Spain, are subject to
i. the first wear. One young American told
me that during a residence of seven years
at Havana and Matanzas, he had it three
times. Few, after all, of mankind will be
willing TO take the chance of life and death,
even of one in ten. Although it must be
admitted that many die from indulging in
habits contracted previously to their resi-
deuce in Cuba; and from the sudden change
of diet and custom. 1t might be well tor
people on that account, to locate themselves
in such public houses as would be found to
correspond most with their previous habits
and manners, particularly during their early
residence in Cuba.


The Island, from its peculiar sslubrity
during the season from November to May,
of course offers great inducements to persons
afflicted with pulmonary complaints. Hence
it is visited great deal on this account
The country is generally preferred to The
cities, and numbers of invalids are found on
the plantations in various parts Of the !slard
full articles.byline:
From Ike N,,c- York Daily .qdrsrtiSer.


LETTER x.

full articles.headline: SINCERITY IN CONVERSATION.
full articles.article:
Amongst too many ether instances OF the
great corruption and degeneracy OF the age
wherein we live, the great and general want
of sincerity in conversation is none of the
last. The world is grown so full OF dissimu-
lation and compliment, that mems words are
hardly any signihcaton of their thoughts
The old plainness and sincerity, that gener-
Gus integrity of nature, and honesty OF dis
position, which always argues true great
ness of mind, and is usually accompanied
with undaunted courage and resolution, is in
great measure lost amongst US.


The dialect of conversation is, now a-days,
so sweled with vanity and compliment, and
so surfeited (if you allow me the expression)
with kindness and respect, that it man
who lived century ago should return into
the world again, he would really want die
tionary to help I'm to understand his own
language, and to know the true intrinsic val
ue of the phrase in fashion and would hard
ly at FIRST believe at what low rate the
highest strains and expressions of kindness
do commonly pass in current payment; and
when he should come to understand it, it
would be a great while before he coald
bring himself, with good countenance and
good conscience, to converse with men up
on equal terms, and in their own way. And.
in truth, it is hard to say, whetherit it should
more provoke our contempt or our pity, TO
hear what selemn expressions of respect ana
Kindness will pass between men, almost up
on no occasion; how great honor and esteem
they will declare for one, whom, perhaps,
they never saw before and how entirely
they are, all on a sudden, devoted to his ser
vice and interest, for no reason I! how inf
nitely and eternally obliged to him, for no
benefit! and how extremely they will be
concerned for him, yea, and afflicted too tor
no cause!

full articles.headline:
TEE LADIES' FRIEND.

WOMAN.
full articles.article:
! Woman is a very nice and very compli-
Gated machine. Her springs are infinitely
delicate: and differ from those ot man pref
ty nearly as the work of a repeating watch
does from that Of town-clock. Look at
her body; how deicatcly formed Exam
inc her senses; how exquisite and nice! Ob-
serve her under standing; how subtle and a
cute! But look inte her heart; composed OF
parts SO minute in themselves, and SO won
derfully combined, that they must be seen
by a microscopic eye to be clearly compre-
hended.


The perception of a woman is as quick as
lightning. Her penetration is intuition; ]
had almost said instinct. BY glance OF
her eve she shall draw deep and ust con-
clusion. Ask her how she formed 1t; she can
not answer the question.


As the perception of women is surprising
ly quick; so their souls and d,imaginations are
uocommonly susceptible Few of them have
culture enough to write; but when they do,
how lively are their pictures! how animat-
ed their descriptions But it few women
write. they all talk; and every man may
Judge of them in this point, from every circ,e
he goes into. Spirit in conversation depends
entirely upon fancy; and women an over the
world talk better than men. Rave they Il
characterize portray, or f1gure 20 oescrlpe!
thev give but three traits of either one or the
other, and the character is known or the
6gure placed before our eyes. Why From
the susceptibility of their imaginatt'ons their
fancies receive lively impressions from those
principal traits, and they paint those I'M
pressions with the same vivacity with which
they receive them. o,vors,
Let a woman of fancy warm in tonversa-
tion, she shall produce hundred charming
images, among which there shall NOT DC Que
indelicare or coarse. Warm man on .ne


same subject; he shall possibly fna s.rohgnr .,;,


allusions, but they shall neither DC 30 oFii-
liant nor SO chaste,

full articles.headline: REMEMBER ME.
full articles.article:
There are not two other words in the lam
guage that call back a more fruitful train ol
past remembranccs of friendship. than these
Look through YOUR library, and when you
cast your eve upon volume that contains
the name of an old compainion, 1t will say
remember me. Have you AN ancient album
the repository Of the mementos Of early
affection! Turn over is leaves, stained by
the finger uf tine--sit down aud ponder up
on the names enrolled upon them; each says
remember me. Gointo the crowded church
ward, among the marble tonbs s-read tine
simple and brief inscriptions tina. perpetuate
the memory Of departed ones; they too have
voice that speaks to the hearts OF the liv-
ing. and it says--remem5er M. Walk in
the hour of evening twilight and the scenes
of YOUR early rambles; the we'll known
maths. the winding streams, the overspread'
ing trees, the green and gently sloping bar rs
will recall the dreams of juvenile pleasure,
and the recollections Of youthful companions;
thev too bear the treasured Injunction
member mr..


And this is all that is left at last of the
wide circle of our early friends. Scattered
by fortune, or called away by death, or
thrown without our band by the changes OF
circumstance or Of character-in time, we
find ourselves alone with the recollection OF
what they were. Snme were our beneiactors
and won us l,y their favors; others were kind,
amiabe and affectionate, and for this we cs-
tecmed them; others again were models otvIr-
tue, and shared our praise and admiration. 1t
wasthus little while, and then the chances OF
the world broke in upon the delightful inter-
course; it ceased. Yet still, we do all we
can to discharge the one sacred, honest and
honorable deht-7ce remember them.


The tribute, too, Of remembrance Which
we delight to pay to others, we desire TOR
ourselves. The wish for applause; the
thirst for fame; the desire that our names
should shine down to future posterity in
the glory Of recorded deeds, is feverish,
unhappy passion, compared with the unam-
bilious desire to retain, even beyond the
span oflfc, the affections ofthe warm heart
ed few who shared our JOYS and sorrows IN
the world. I once read the bret inscription


-'remember me, on tomb stone IN a coun-
try church ward, with tear, that the grave
oe Bonaparte would not have called forth.


But whom do we always remember with
affrction9 the virtuous, the kind, the warm
hearted: those who have endearc1 them
selves to us BY the amiableness Of their char
actors. 1t is the mind. the disposition, the
habits, the feelings of our friends whish at
toch us to them most strongly; which form
the oulv lasting bond of affection; Which
lone can secure our affectionate remembran-
ces


Then if we would be remembered with
the kindliest feelings; if We would be en-
balmed in the memory If those we love, IT


we desire that when fortune or fate shall
seperate US from our friends, they may long
t,;nt of ne. we must Dossess ourselves the
same cbaracteY VIC love in others. Never
was there more noble line written in the
history of man, than this-'the first emotion
of pain he ever causeI-was caused by his
departure

full articles.headline: No. 46.
full articles.article:
know it is said, in justification of this
hollow kind of conversation, that there is
no harm, no real deceit, in compliment-but
that the matter is well enough, so long as we
understand one anothcr:-yer6a Uaienf ut
numni-7vords are like money:-and when
the current value of them is generally un-
derstood, no man is cheated by them. This
is something, if such words are any thing;
but, being brought into the account, they
are mere ciphers.-However, it is just mat
ter of compliment, that sincerity and hlain-
ness are out of fashion, and that our Lam
guage is running into lie; that men have
almost perverted the use of speech, and
made words to signify nothing; that the
greater part of the conversation of mankind
is little else but driving trade of Gissimu-
latjon. insomuch, that it would make a man
sick and weary of the world to see the little
sincerity that is in use and practice among
men.


lfthe show of any thing be good for any
thing, am sure sincerity is better; for why
does any man dissemble, or seem to be that
which he is not. but because he thinks it
good to have such quality as he pretends
to- for to counterfeit and dssemble, is to
put on the appearance of some real excel
lency. Now the best way in the world to
seem to be any thing, is really to be what he
would seem to be. Besides that. it is many
times as troublesome to make good the pre-
tence of a good quality, as to have it; and if
man has it not, it is ten to one but he is
discovered to want it; and then all his pains
and labor to seem to have it, are lost. What
soever convenience may be thought to be
in taischood and dissimulation, it is soon over;
but the inconvenience OF it is perpetual be-
cause it brings man under AN everlasting
,a,l1 !. g. L.
lieved when he speaks the truth-nor trust
ed when perhaps he means honesty. When
tnan has once forfeited the reputation of
his Integrity, he is set free; and nothing will
then serve his turn, neither truth nor false
hood.

Effects Of Moonlight uhon the Eyes,
The effect ofthe mo 'nlight on the eyes, in
Egypt, is sngularly injurious: the natives
tell you, as found afterwards they did in
Arabia, to cover your eyes when you sleep
in the open air. The moon in Egypt strikes
and affects the sight, when you sleep expos
ed to it, much more than the sun; a fact Of
which l had very unpleasant proof one
night, and took care to guard against it at-
terwards; indeed, the sight of a person who
should sleep with his face exposed at night
would soon be utterly impaired or destroyed,

full articles.headline: AN AWKWARD COMPLIMENT.
full articles.article:
Many years ago, the judges on one of the
circuits were detained so late on Saturday
night, at a certain assize town, that being
obliged to op'n the commission at the next
town On the Monday following they were
compelled, much against their will to travel
between the two places on the Sabbath dav;
but to do this with decent and jnaee-like
proprietv, it was SO managed that they
should breakfast at an inconsidcrable town.
or rather village, about half way-stay and
attend divine service there--and then pro-


ceed to their destination.


On their arrival at this midway hamlet,


whose rustic inhahitants were in that torpid
and dreamy state so common in a small coIn-
try place, and who AS much expected his
majesty in person. as two of his malesty's
Judges. at their little church on that day,
the landlord of the village ale-house, called
by courtesy an inn, was made acquainted


with their intentions, and instantly despatch
ed his head waiter, alias pot boy, alias host
Ter to the SEXTON, with the marvellous IT,
linps: the sexton made il known to the over
seers. church wardens. and rector; they to
.heiy resDectivc wives; their wives to all the
housema,ds. nurscmaids, and cooks; till, by
some freemasonrv sign, some tfleEraph'c
movement or some other occult mode OF
communication, the whole parish knew OF
the intended honor, before their legal lord
eh;ps had dispatched the comfortable and
substantial breakfast, which mine host of
the Red Lion, with an inhnitude OF bows,
scrapes, and apologies, had set before them
Great was the rummaging ot trunks, and
tumblinp over of the contents of drawers, on
this eventful morning; all the best blbs and
fuckers were had in requisition; the SILK
pown of the elderly dame, and the delicate


white muslin envelope of the younger lady,
were brought forth; and much was the RI


varv of the female part OF the congregation;


while the gentlemen were not oehino-nanu
in furnishing up their attire, and even the
rustic laborers gave their shoes ana hlgh-
Ions an extra polish, and hid their sunday
clothes under their whitest and best stitch-
ed smock trocks. All, in short, were de-
termined to do their best to show the Judg-
es that they we're properly sensible OF tne
high honor done them; and more especiai-
". all those in authority, From the rector
down to the parsh-clerK, maze up ther
minds to do something that might be pleas
ing to their unexpected visiters.


First. a sort of procession was formed,
consisting of the old beadle, areheaded,
hearing his tarnished laced hat in one hand,
and his staff of Office in the other; then came
the overseers. and then the church wardens,
bearing certain willow wands in their hands,
which had been rudely separated from their
native stems. and hastily stripped OF their
bark for the great occasion, last but not
least. came the well-fed rector, side by side
with the Judges, and honored as he walked
by sundry scraps oftheir learned conversa,,
ton. Thus they reached the ivy-covered
fame; the inhabitants, cap in hand, forming
an avenue from the gate of the churchyard
to the door of the church, and were usher
ed into the only pew conscious of once green
baize, but which had become venerably vel,
low by extreme old age. The church had
not been so still. during divine service, per-
haps for ages; the wayward urchins, who
generally contrived, by their contumacious
Behaviour, their munching of apples. or
cracking Of nuts, to get lasts OF the hea-

hrokena And the remembrance of earthly
scenes, are they indeed to the enfranchised
spirit as the morning dream, or the dew up


on the early Howers Reflections such as


these naturally arise in every breast. Their


influence is felt, though their import cannot


always be expressed. The principle is the


same, however it may differ in its opera
tions.o

:. The annexed paragraph is an eloquent de-
hneation of what all can feel, but Jew can
Soeloquently describe. 1t is from the novel
e0t'tIed-"Narriage"-a work written with
uncommon power and ability.


There is, perhaps, no feeling of our ma"
.ure SO vague complicated, SO mysterious, as
mat with which we look upon the cold re-
mans of our fellow mortals. The dignity
with which death invests the meanest OF its
victims, inspires us with an awe no living
creature can create. The monarch on his
.lrone is less awful than the beggar in his
,,'roud. The marble features-the power
'ess hand-the stiffened limb--oh! who can
sso'nntemplate these with feelings that can be
SSehhed! These are the mockery of all our
hh0pes and fears, our fondest love, our tellest
hha'e' Can it he, that we now shrink with
n no'ror from the touch Of that hand which but
33tes.ercay was fondly clasped in our own! Is
o' o"a' tongue, whose accents even now dwell IN
Tn TSl forever chained in the silence of death!
foas fSnese black and heavy eye-lids, are they
wher teVer TO seal up in darkness the eyes
strs; an1se glance no earthly power could re-
elm And the spirit which animated the
o. , s; wnere is it now? 1t is wrapped in bliss
~ a,ssolved in woe! Does it witness our grief,
TO- ~ snare our sorrows? Or is the mysterious
h2ss tnat linked il with mortality forever

full articles.headline:
ysyg1 MDNITON.

DEATH.
full articles.article:
All must die; kings, princes must obey
The freezing CALI Statesmen must ono day


stoop


Iopay their court to the despotic tomb;
Lawyers must there refund the fee of life;
Heroes. unarrned, forgetting sieges. battles,
Must, far from glory, and the sound ofpraise,
lake their last stations inspired orators
Must shun the multitude, whose mind they made,
And cleave to silence and oblivion.
The player must desert his mimic scene,
T., 10 die indeed; and poets, fond of hope.
With their fine sense of life, must humble too,
And, at the summons, quit Castalia's springs,
10 plunge amid the gloom Of Erebus.


us to the wretch alone that he denies
The solacc of his slcep. Conscience.

dies cane. were dumb .foundered by the
presence of men. who they imagined had
the power TO transport them-nay, hang
them, for aught they knew, for any III De-
haviour, or appearance of contempt, in their
august society.


Service degan. The rustic choir endcav-
ored to "snatch grace beyond the reach of
art" but some of their tongues seemed to
tceave to the roofs of their mouths; the rec
tors sermon was the best he could pick out
from his bundle Of ffty-two, or thereabouts,
which bundle having served for one year,
was then turned round and served mighti-
ly well for the next also; his auditors. sim
! pie souls never suspecting that they were
getting the same dose over again.


At this church, the custom was to dismiss
the congregation with psalm, or portion
os one; and the clerk (who was a celebrat-
ed singer Of profane melodies at the Red
Lion atoresaid) generally reserved his best
piece of psalmody to conclude with; and at
the time in question, being determined, like
all the rest, to immortalize himself as much
as might be. he looked into the index to the
psalms, and finding that the ffty-eighth
psalm began With Speak, 0 We Judges of
the earth" he thought he had hit upon the
very thing that would do; and when the rev.
erend rector had concluded his sermon,
boldly gave out the first four verses of the
aforesaid psalm, expecting, no doubt, APP
plause and reward accordingly. The pitch
pipe granted and groaned, the singers growl-
"a their stcntorian voices into something
like unison, and off they went in grand
st, le, and sang as follows:


"Spcak, ye Judges Of the earth,
If Just your sentence be;


Or must not innocence appeal


To heaven from your decree'


Your wicked hearts and iudments are


Alike by malice swave;


Your gripping hands, by weighty bribes,


To violence betrayed.


To virtue, strangers from the womb,


Their infant steps went wrong


They prattle SANDER, and in lies


Employed their lispng tongue.


No scrpe' of pnrched Africa's breed


Doth ranker poison bear;


The drowsy adder will soon


Unlock his sullen ear"


1t may readily be supposed that the con-
gregation presently began to find out that
the clerks compliment was completely mai
GhrohoS; as to those who were called, par
excellence, the regular singers, they went
on with their work as loud as usual; not be-
ing in the habit oftroubing thel heads about
the import of the words they were singing;
but those Of the congre cation who some
times helped them in their chanting, and
who on this occasion, began as usual, upon
finding the tenor (this is not meant for mu-
sca pun) of the psalm, dropped their voices
one after another, ard left all the glory and
the shame to the singing pew. The clerk
too was frightened out of lis wits, or there
abouts, at what he had done; and doubtless
expected some dreadful visitation from the
strong arm If the law for his temerity;
while same Of the neighbours were not quite
sure whether heavy fine would not be
lain upon the parish for the insult; in short,
these four verses Of the fifty-eight psalm had
thrown complete gloom upon the day
